Award.AwardTitle: The emergence of diagnostic reasoning and scientific thinking.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, a collaboration between Brown University and Providence Children's Museum (PCM) focuses on investigating children's developing social cognition, particularly about how and why knowledge mediates the development of diagnostic reasoning. The research team will explore tools for use by informal science institutions like children's museums, science centers, and zoos. These tools may be used to support children's metacognition around diagnostic reasoning and causal learning as well as more broadly along with caregivers' understanding of their children's learning processes in informal science education (ISE) settings. Deliverables include: (a) a workshop and research manual for museum professionals; (b) a blog; (c) a cross-discipline literature review on metacognition and making learning visible; (d) reports from focus groups and interviews with caregivers and children at PCM focused on learning and play in the museum context; (e) a range of tools designed to help children and their caregivers become aware of their metacognitive processes; (f) exhibit labels and other communication tools for visitors to the museum; and (g) a permanent Mind Lab space at PCM that will be used to communicate the work of the partnership and research to the public. These deliverables will inform the development of a model of practice that ISE professionals can employ when working with children and their caregivers with the goal of making their learning and learning processes visible.

This research project will advance the field by building theoretical understanding around children's reasoning and scientific thinking. It will also build capacity among academic researchers and informal science education researchers, educators, and administrators by providing empirical support for pedagogical decisions and strategies employed on a daily basis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to investigate a discrepancy: Young children have sophisticated causal reasoning abilities that underlie early forms of scientific thinking. Yet, scientific reasoning is challenging – even adults can struggle to interpret patterns of evidence or design well-controlled experiments. To investigate this discrepancy, this project looked at how children’s emerging diagnostic reasoning abilities (their ability to make judgments about the potential causes of an event), coupled with their developing metacognition (their ability to reflect on their own thinking and learning), allow them to make inferences similar to those made by scientists when evaluating the results of an experiment. We discovered that some diagnostic reasoning skills have a prolonged developmental trajectory during the elementary school years, and that causal inferences that might be used in scientific investigations are related to children’s developing metacognitive abilities, particularly their understanding of learning and science as active processes.

 

In conducting these investigations, the research team examined how children begin to reflect on concepts like science, learning, teaching, and play, in order to shed light on children’s developing metacognitive awareness of their own thinking. We investigated how children talk about these concepts, and documented in multiple studies that children’s definitions of these concepts related to other developing skills: Children’s descriptions of science related to their causal inferences in other tasks; Children’s descriptions of learning and teaching related to their ability to reflect on how they learned, how they had been taught, and how they taught others in their own lives; and children’s descriptions of play and pretending related to their judgments about scenarios involving pretending and their ability to reflect on the ways that they play. The way children talk about these abstract concepts not only offers insight into how they understand those concepts but also shows how they engage in these behaviors in their own lives.

 

The project brought together researchers in cognitive development and museum practitioners on both a local and more global level. Locally, the project supported the creation of a permanent space for the Mind Lab program at Providence Children’s Museum. Mind Lab involves families at the Museum in ongoing research, and in the process, disseminates research findings and communicates the importance of developmental science to the public. The most important goal of Mind Lab is to make children’s learning processes more visible to museum visitors. Research studies encourage caregivers to reflect on their child’s learning by demonstrating how scientists study children’s development and providing opportunities for caregivers to learn about the findings of current research.

 

At the Museum, the project resulted in new strategies for making learning visible to both children and caregivers during their Museum visits. The project team conducted literature reviews, observations, and discussions with Museum educators and caregivers to understand how children demonstrate thinking and learning in their play at the Museum, and in particular, the ways they begin to reflect on their own thinking. The team used the findings to develop and test new exhibit materials to highlight how children learn through play and exploration at the Museum. Resources prototyped during the project included labels in Mind Lab based on current research and the Museum’s Learning Frameworks, illustrated summaries of individual research studies on children’s learning (including studies completed through the Mind Lab program), new signage in multiple Museum exhibits with observable examples of learning in children’s play, a circuit block activity and accompanying resources for caregivers to help them notice and support children’s learning, a play observation tool and photo-mission activity to encourage caregivers to document children’s learning in the moment, and a video kiosk for families to reflect together about play. Together, these prototyping efforts allowed the Museum to identify effective strategies for raising awareness about the value of play for children’s learning and development.

 

More globally, the PI co-edited Cognitive Development in Museum Settings: Relating Research to Practice. This volume discusses partnerships between cognitive development researchers and museums (including science centers and children’s museums) and how research informs practice in these settings, and vice versa. The main chapters are co-authored by researchers and museum practitioners currently engaged in partnerships. Each group describes the history of their partnership, the research outcomes that have emerged because of the partnership, ways in which museum practices and the direction of the research have been shaped by the partnership, and the benefits and challenges of working together. Notable scholars in both research and practice provide commentary on the potential of these endeavors for generating new knowledge about children’s learning, and suggest strategies for strengthening these types of partnerships and avoiding common pitfalls.

 

In sum, this project has resulted in research findings on the development of children’s scientific thinking and metacognition, as well as practical tools for Museum visitors and educators, and resources for scientists and practitioners engaged in similar partnerships.
